TEXT: A noise of bolts was now heard, the door opened, and two men appeared. One was short, very muscular, broad-shouldered, with robust limbs, strong head, an abundance of black hair, thick moustache, a quick penetrating look, and the vivacity which characterises the population of [Southern France]_n0. The second stranger merits a more detailed description. [I]_p0 made out [his]_p1 prevailing qualities directly: self-confidence, because [his]_p2 head was well set on [his]_p2 shoulders, and [his]_p3 black eyes looked around with cold assurance calmness, for [his]_p3 skin, rather pale, showed [his]_p3 coolness of blood energy, evinced by the rapid contraction of [his]_p4 lofty brows and courage, because [his]_p4 deep breathing denoted great power of lungs. Whether this person was thirty-five or fifty years of age, [I]_p9 could not say. [He]_p10 was tall, had a large forehead, straight nose, a clearly cut mouth, beautiful teeth, with fine taper hands, indicative of a highly nervous temperament. This man was certainly the most admirable specimen [I]_p11 had ever met. One particular feature was [his]_p12 eyes, rather far from each other, and which could take in nearly a quarter of the horizon at once. This faculty, (I verified [it]_p13 later), gave [him]_p14 a range of vision far superior to [Ned Land]_n1 's. When this stranger fixed upon an object, [his]_p15 eyebrows met, [his]_p16 large eyelids closed around so as to contract the range of [his]_p16 vision, and [he]_p18 looked as if [he]_p19 magnified the objects lessened by distance, as if [he]_p19 pierced those sheets of water so opaque to [our]_p22 eyes, and as if [he]_p20 read the very depths of the seas.

The two strangers, with caps made from the fur of the sea otter, and shod with sea boots of seal's skin, were dressed in clothes of a particular texture, which allowed free movement of the limbs. The taller of the two, evidently the chief on board, examined [us]_p23 with great attention, without saying a word then, turning to [his]_p24 companion, talked with [him]_p25 in an unknown tongue. [It]_p26 was a sonorous, harmonious, and flexible dialect, the vowels seeming to admit of very varied accentuation. The other replied by a shake of the head, and added two or three perfectly incomprehensible words. Then [he]_p27 seemed to question [me]_p28 by a look. [I]_p29 replied in good [French]_n2 that [I]_p30 did not know [his]_p31 language but [he]_p32 seemed not to understand me, and [my]_p33 situation became more embarrassing. "If master were to tell [our]_p34 story," said [Conseil]_n3 , "perhaps these gentlemen may understand some words. " [I]_p35 began to tell [our]_p36 adventures, articulating each syllable clearly, and without omitting one single detail. [I]_p37 announced [our]_p38 names and rank, introducing in person [Professor Aronnax]_n4 , [his]_p39 servant [Conseil]_n5 , and master [Ned Land]_n6 , the harpooner. The man with the soft calm eyes listened to [me]_p40 quietly, even politely, and with extreme attention but nothing in [his]_p41 countenance indicated that [he]_p42 had understood [my]_p43 story.

When [I]_p44 finished, [he]_p45 said not a word. There remained one resource, to speak [English]_n7. Perhaps [they]_p46 would know this almost universal language. [I]_p47 knew it, as well as the German language, well enough to read [it]_p48 fluently, but not to speak [it]_p49 correctly. But, anyhow, [we]_p51 must make [ourselves]_p52 understood. "Go on in [your]_p53 turn," [I]_p55 said to the harpooner "speak [your]_p54 best [Anglo-Saxon]_n8 , and try to do better than I. " [Ned]_n9 did not beg off, and recommenced [our]_p57 story. To [his]_p58 great disgust, the harpooner did not seem to have made [himself]_p59 more intelligible than [I]_p60 had. [Our]_p61 visitors did not stir. [They]_p62 evidently understood neither the language of [England]_n10 nor of [France]_n11.

Very much embarrassed, after having vainly exhausted [our]_p63 speaking resources, [I]_p64 knew not what part to take, when [Conseil]_n12 said: "If master will permit me, [I]_p65 will relate [it]_p66 in German. " But in spite of the elegant terms and good accent of the narrator, the German language had no success. At last, nonplussed, [I]_p67 tried to remember [my]_p68 first lessons, and to narrate [our]_p69 adventures in [Latin]_n13 , but with no better success. This last attempt being of no avail, the two strangers exchanged some words in [their]_p70 unknown language, and retired. The door shut. "It is an infamous shame," cried [Ned Land]_n14 , who broke out for the twentieth time. "We speak to those rogues in [French]_n15 , [English]_n16 , German, and [Latin]_n17 , and not one of [them]_p71 has the politeness to answer!" "Calm yourself," [I]_p72 said to the impetuous [Ned]_n18 "anger will do no good. " "But do [you]_p73 see, [Professor]_n19 ," replied [our]_p74 irascible companion, "that [we]_p75 shall absolutely die of hunger in this iron cage?" "[Bah]_n20 !" said [Conseil]_n21 , philosophically "we can hold out some time yet. " "My friends," [I]_p77 said, "we must not despair. [We]_p78 have been worse off than this.

Do [me]_p79 the favour to wait a little before forming an opinion upon the commander and crew of this boat. " "My opinion is formed," replied [Ned Land]_n22 , sharply. "They are rascals. " "Good! and from what country?" "From the land of rogues!" "My brave [Ned]_n23 , that country is not clearly indicated on the map of the world but [I]_p80 admit that the nationality of the two strangers is hard to determine. Neither [English]_n24 , [French]_n25 , nor German, that is quite certain. However, [I]_p81 am inclined to think that the commander and [his]_p82 companion were born in low latitudes. There is southern blood in them. But [I]_p83 cannot decide by [their]_p84 appearance whether [they]_p85 are Spaniards, Turks, Arabians, or Indians. As to [their]_p86 language, [it]_p87 is quite incomprehensible. " "There is the disadvantage of not knowing all languages," said [Conseil]_n26 , "or the disadvantage of not having one universal language.

" As [he]_p88 said these words, the door opened. A steward entered. [He]_p89 brought [us]_p90 clothes, coats and trousers, made of a stuff [I]_p91 did not know. [I]_p92 hastened to dress myself, and [my]_p93 companions followed [my]_p94 example. During that time, the steward, dumb, perhaps deaf, had arranged the table, and laid three plates. "This is something like!" said [Conseil]_n27. "[Bah]_n28 !" said the angry harpooner, "what do [you]_p95 suppose [they]_p96 eat here? [Tortoise]_n29 liver, filleted shark, and beef steaks from seadogs. " "We shall see," said [Conseil]_n30. The dishes, of bell metal, were placed on the table, and [we]_p97 took [our]_p98 places. Undoubtedly [we]_p99 had to do with civilised people, and, had [it]_p100 not been for the electric light which flooded us, [I]_p101 could have fancied [I]_p102 was in the dining-room of the [Adelphi Hotel]_n31 at [Liverpool]_n32 , or at the [Grand Hotel]_n33 in [Paris]_n34.

[I]_p103 must say, however, that there was neither bread nor wine. The water was fresh and clear, but [it]_p104 was water and did not suit [Ned Land]_n35 's taste. Amongst the dishes which were brought to us, [I]_p105 recognised several fish delicately dressed but of some, although excellent, [I]_p106 could give no opinion, neither could [I]_p106 tell to what kingdom [they]_p108 belonged, whether animal or vegetable. As to the dinner-service, [it]_p109 was elegant, and in perfect taste. Each utensil, spoon, fork, knife, plate, had a letter engraved on it, with a motto above it, of which this is an exact facsimile: MOBILIS IN MOBILI N The letter N was no doubt the initial of the name of the enigmatical person who commanded at the bottom of the seas. [Ned]_n36 and [Conseil]_n37 did not reflect much. [They]_p110 devoured the food, and [I]_p111 did likewise. [I]_p112 was, besides, reassured as to [our]_p113 fate and [it]_p115 seemed evident that [our]_p114 hosts would not let [us]_p116 die of want. However, everything has an end, everything passes away, even the hunger of people who have not eaten for fifteen hours. [Our]_p117 appetites satisfied, [we]_p118 felt overcome with sleep.

"Faith! [I]_p119 shall sleep well," said [Conseil]_n38. "So shall I," replied [Ned Land]_n39. [My]_p120 two companions stretched [themselves]_p121 on the cabin carpet, and were soon sound asleep. For [my]_p122 own part, too many thoughts crowded [my]_p123 brain, too many insoluble questions pressed upon me, too many fancies kept [my]_p123 eyes half open. Where were we? What strange power carried [us]_p125 on? [I]_p126 felt, or rather fancied [I]_p127 felt, the machine sinking down to the lowest beds of the sea. Dreadful nightmares beset [me]_p128 [I]_p129 saw in these mysterious asylums a world of unknown animals, amongst which this submarine boat seemed to be of the same kind, living, moving, and formidable as they. Then [my]_p130 brain grew calmer, [my]_p131 imagination wandered into vague unconsciousness, and [I]_p132 soon fell into a deep sleep. CHAPTER IX [NED LAND]_n40 'S TEMPERS How long [we]_p133 slept [I]_p134 do not know but [our]_p135 sleep must have lasted long, for [it]_p137 rested [us]_p138 completely from [our]_p136 fatigues. [I]_p139 woke first. [My]_p140 companions had not moved, and were still stretched in [their]_p141 corner.

Hardly roused from [my]_p142 somewhat hard couch, [I]_p145 felt [my]_p143 brain freed, [my]_p143 mind clear. [I]_p146 then began an attentive examination of [our]_p147 cell. Nothing was changed inside. The prison was still a prison, the prisoners, prisoners. However, the steward, during [our]_p148 sleep, had cleared the table. [I]_p149 breathed with difficulty. The heavy air seemed to oppress [my]_p150 lungs. Although the cell was large, [we]_p151 had evidently consumed a great part of the oxygen that [it]_p152 contained. Indeed, each man consumes, in one hour, the oxygen contained in more than 176 pints of air, and this air, charged (as then) with a nearly equal quantity of carbonic acid, becomes unbreathable. [It]_p153 became necessary to renew the atmosphere of [our]_p154 prison, and no doubt the whole in the submarine boat.

That gave rise to a question in [my]_p155 mind. How would the commander of this floating dwelling-place proceed? Would [he]_p156 obtain air by chemical means, in getting by heat the oxygen contained in chlorate of potash, and in absorbing carbonic acid by caustic potash? [Or]_n41 , a more convenient, economical, and consequently more probable alternative, would [he]_p157 be satisfied to rise and take breath at the surface of the water, like a whale, and so renew for twenty-four hours the atmospheric provision? In fact, [I]_p158 was already obliged to increase [my]_p160 respirations to eke out of this cell the little oxygen [it]_p161 contained, when suddenly [I]_p159 was refreshed by a current of pure air, and perfumed with saline emanations. [It]_p162 was an invigorating sea breeze, charged with iodine. [I]_p163 opened [my]_p164 mouth wide, and [my]_p165 lungs saturated [themselves]_p166 with fresh particles. At the same time [I]_p167 felt the boat rolling. The iron-plated monster had evidently just risen to the surface of the ocean to breathe, after the fashion of whales. [I]_p168 found out from that the mode of ventilating the boat. When [I]_p169 had inhaled this air freely, [I]_p170 sought the conduit pipe, which conveyed to [us]_p172 the beneficial whiff, and [I]_p170 was not long in finding it. Above the door was a ventilator, through which volumes of fresh air renewed the impoverished atmosphere of the cell. [I]_p173 was making [my]_p174 observations, when [Ned]_n42 and [Conseil]_n43 awoke almost at the same time, under the influence of this reviving air.

[They]_p175 rubbed [their]_p176 eyes, stretched themselves, and were on [their]_p177 feet in an instant. "Did master sleep well?" asked [Conseil]_n44 , with [his]_p178 usual politeness. "Very well, [my]_p179 brave boy. And you, [Mr Land]_n45 ?" "Soundly, [Professor]_n46. But, [I]_p180 don't know if [I]_p181 am right or not, there seems to be a sea breeze!" A seaman could not be mistaken, and [I]_p181 told the [Canadian]_n47 all that had passed during [his]_p183 sleep. "Good!" said he. "That accounts for those roarings [we]_p184 heard, when the supposed narwhal sighted the [Abraham Lincoln]_n48. " "Quite so, [Master Land]_n49 [it]_p185 was taking breath. " "Only, [Mr Aronnax]_n50 , [I]_p186 have no idea what o'clock [it]_p187 is, unless [it]_p188 is dinner-time. " "Dinner-time! [my]_p189 good fellow? Say rather breakfast-time, for [we]_p190 certainly have begun another day.

" "So," said [Conseil]_n51 , "we have slept twenty-four hours?" "That is [my]_p191 opinion. " "I will not contradict you," replied [Ned Land]_n52. "But, dinner or breakfast, the steward will be welcome, whichever [he]_p192 brings. " "[Master Land]_n53 , [we]_p193 must conform to the rules on board, and [I]_p194 suppose [our]_p195 appetites are in advance of the dinner hour. " "That is just like you, friend [Conseil]_n54 ," said [Ned]_n55 , impatiently. "You are never out of temper, always calm [you]_p196 would return thanks before grace, and die of hunger rather than complain!" Time was getting on, and [we]_p197 were fearfully hungry and this time the steward did not appear. [It]_p198 was rather too long to leave us, if [they]_p199 really had good intentions towards us. [Ned Land]_n56 , tormented by the cravings of hunger, got still more angry and, notwithstanding [his]_p200 promise, [I]_p201 dreaded an explosion when [he]_p202 found [himself]_p203 with one of the crew. For two hours more [Ned Land]_n57 's temper increased [he]_p204 cried, [he]_p205 shouted, but in vain. The walls were deaf.

There was no sound to be heard in the boat all was still as death. [It]_p206 did not move, for [I]_p207 should have felt the trembling motion of the hull under the influence of the screw. Plunged in the depths of the waters, [it]_p208 belonged no longer to earth: this silence was dreadful. [I]_p209 felt terrified, [Conseil]_n58 was calm, [Ned Land]_n59 roared. Just then a noise was heard outside. Steps sounded on the metal flags. The locks were turned, the door opened, and the steward appeared. Before [I]_p210 could rush forward to stop him, the [Canadian]_n60 had thrown [him]_p211 down, and held [him]_p212 by the throat. The steward was choking under the grip of [his]_p214 powerful hand. [Conseil]_n61 was already trying to unclasp the harpooner's hand from [his]_p215 half-suffocated victim, and [I]_p216 was going to fly to the rescue, when suddenly [I]_p217 was nailed to the spot by hearing these words in [French]_n62 : "Be quiet, [Master Land]_n63 and you, [Professor]_n64 , will [you]_p218 be so good as to listen to me?" CHAPTER X THE MAN OF THE [SEAS]_n65 [It]_p220 was the commander of the vessel who thus spoke.

At these words, [Ned Land]_n66 rose suddenly. The steward, nearly strangled, tottered out on a sign from [his]_p221 master. But such was the power of the commander on board, that not a gesture betrayed the resentment which this man must have felt towards the [Canadian]_n67. [Conseil]_n68 interested in spite of himself, [I]_p222 stupefied, awaited in silence the result of this scene. The commander, leaning against the corner of a table with [his]_p223 arms folded, scanned [us]_p224 with profound attention. Did [he]_p225 hesitate to speak? Did [he]_p226 regret the words which [he]_p226 had just spoken in [French]_n69 ? [One]_p228 might almost think so. After some moments of silence, which not one of [us]_p229 dreamed of breaking, "[Gentlemen]_n70 ," said he, in a calm and penetrating voice, "I speak [French]_n71 , [English]_n72 , German, and [Latin]_n73 equally well. [I]_p230 could, therefore, have answered [you]_p232 at [our]_p234 first interview, but [I]_p231 wished to know [you]_p233 first, then to reflect. The story told by each one, entirely agreeing in the main points, convinced [me]_p235 of [your]_p236 identity. [I]_p237 know now that chance has brought before [me]_p238 M.

[Pierre Aronnax]_n74 , [Professor]_n75 of [Natural]_n76 History at the [Museum]_n77 of [Paris]_n78 , entrusted with a scientific mission abroad, [Conseil]_n79 , [his]_p239 servant, and [Ned Land]_n80 , of [Canadian]_n81 origin, harpooner on board the frigate [Abraham Lincoln]_n82 of the navy of the [United States]_n83 of [America]_n84. " [I]_p240 bowed assent. [It]_p241 was not a question that the commander put to me. Therefore there was no answer to be made. This man expressed [himself]_p242 with perfect ease, without any accent. [His]_p243 sentences were well turned, [his]_p244 words clear, and [his]_p245 fluency of speech remarkable. Yet, [I]_p246 did not recognise in [him]_p247 a fellow-countryman. [He]_p248 continued the conversation in these terms: "You have doubtless thought, sir, that [I]_p249 have delayed long in paying [you]_p250 this second visit. The reason is that, [your]_p251 identity recognised, [I]_p252 wished to weigh maturely what part to act towards you. [I]_p253 have hesitated much.

Most annoying circumstances have brought [you]_p254 into the presence of a man who has broken all the ties of humanity. [You]_p255 have come to trouble [my]_p256 existence. " "Unintentionally!" said I. "Unintentionally?" replied the stranger, raising [his]_p257 voice a little. "Was [it]_p258 unintentionally that the [Abraham Lincoln]_n85 pursued [me]_p262 all over the seas? Was [it]_p259 unintentionally that [you]_p264 took passage in this frigate? Was [it]_p259 unintentionally that [your]_p265 cannon-balls rebounded off the plating of [my]_p266 vessel? Was [it]_p260 unintentionally that [Mr Ned Land]_n86 struck [me]_p263 with [his]_p267 harpoon?" [I]_p268 detected a restrained irritation in these words. But to these recriminations [I]_p269 had a very natural answer to make, and [I]_p270 made it. "Sir," said I, "no doubt [you]_p271 are ignorant of the discussions which have taken place concerning [you]_p272 in [America]_n87 and [Europe]_n88. [You]_p273 do not know that divers accidents, caused by collisions with [your]_p274 submarine machine, have excited public feeling in the two continents. [I]_p275 omit the theories without number by which [it]_p276 was sought to explain that of which [you]_p277 alone possess the secret. But [you]_p278 must understand that, in pursuing [you]_p279 over the high seas of the [Pacific]_n89 , the [Abraham Lincoln]_n90 believed [itself]_p280 to be chasing some powerful sea-monster, of which [it]_p281 was necessary to rid the ocean at any price.

" A half-smile curled the lips of the commander: then, in a calmer tone: "M. [Aronnax]_n91 ," [he]_p282 replied, "dare [you]_p283 affirm that [your]_p284 frigate would not as soon have pursued and cannonaded a submarine boat as a monster?" This question embarrassed me, for certainly [Captain Farragut]_n92 might not have hesitated. [He]_p285 might have thought [it]_p286 [his]_p287 duty to destroy a contrivance of this kind, as [he]_p288 would a gigantic narwhal. "You understand then, sir," continued the stranger, "that [I]_p289 have the right to treat [you]_p291 as enemies?" [I]_p290 answered nothing, purposely. For what good would [it]_p292 be to discuss such a proposition, when force could destroy the best arguments? "I have hesitated some time," continued the commander "nothing obliged [me]_p293 to show [you]_p294 hospitality. If [I]_p295 chose to separate [myself]_p299 from you, [I]_p296 should have no interest in seeing [you]_p300 again [I]_p296 could place [you]_p301 upon the deck of this vessel which has served [you]_p301 as a refuge, [I]_p297 could sink beneath the waters, and forget that [you]_p302 had ever existed. Would not that be [my]_p305 right?" "It might be the right of a savage," [I]_p306 answered, "but not that of a civilised man. " "[Professor]_n93 ," replied the commander, quickly, "I am not what [you]_p310 call a civilised man! [I]_p307 have done with society entirely, for reasons which [I]_p308 alone have the right of appreciating. [I]_p311 do not, therefore, obey [its]_p313 laws, and [I]_p312 desire [you]_p314 never to allude to [them]_p315 before [me]_p316 again!" This was said plainly. A flash of anger and disdain kindled in the eyes of the Unknown, and [I]_p317 had a glimpse of a terrible past in the life of this man.

Not only had [he]_p318 put [himself]_p324 beyond the pale of human laws, but [he]_p319 had made [himself]_p325 independent of them, free in the strictest acceptation of the word, quite beyond [their]_p326 reach! Who then would dare to pursue [him]_p327 at the bottom of the sea, when, on [its]_p330 surface, [he]_p319 defied all attempts made against him? What vessel could resist the shock of [his]_p331 submarine monitor? What cuirass, however thick, could withstand the blows of [his]_p332 spur? No man could demand from [him]_p328 an account of [his]_p332 actions God, if [he]_p320 believed in one, [his]_p333 conscience, if [he]_p320 had one, were the sole judges to whom [he]_p320 was answerable. These reflections crossed [my]_p335 mind rapidly, whilst the stranger personage was silent, absorbed, and as if wrapped up in himself. [I]_p336 regarded [him]_p337 with fear mingled with interest, as, doubtless, [OEdiphus]_n94 regarded the [Sphinx]_n95. After rather a long silence, the commander resumed the conversation.
